prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 continuum: Protoplanetary Disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is a project to measure the spectral slopes of the brightest Class IIs in Auriga in the submm/mm regime.
This science goal is for the Band 3 (100 GHz) observations which link the ALMA observations to the 7mm JVLA observations

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a sensitivity to detect 0.01 Msolar disk with a S/N of 20. This results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.03 mJy/beam.
The requested observations are sensitive to disks above the median disk mass of 0.005 Msolar in Taurus, rho Ophiuchus, and Orion (beyond the Trapezium cluster). We expect this to be sufficient to detect the AMC disks, as we have selected the brightest disks in Herschel maps (70 micron - 500 micron) and therefore expect these to be the most massive disks in the cloud. Disks with this mass were at the lower limit of ~20 disk masses that have been compiled over the years with the SMA (however they only had a S/N of 3).
We request the same mass sensitivity for Band 6 and Band 9 science goals.
The angular resolution requested is to resolve and therefore measure disk sizes. Disk radii in other regions are typically on the order of ~100 AU. Our requested angular resolution of 0.45" corresponds to ~200 AU at the AMC's distance. We request a maximum recoverable scale 10x this to safely account for the range in disk sizes without requiring configurations that are too compact and will result in shadowing for the AMC's declination (~35 degree). This angular resolution is requested to reasonably match the requested angular resolution of 0.35" in the Band 6, Band 7, and Band 9 science goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 continuum: Protoplanetary Disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is a project to measure the spectral slopes of the brightest Class IIs in Auriga in the submm/mm regime.
This science goal is for the Band 6 (230 GHz) observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a sensitivity to detect 0.01 Msolar disk with a S/N of 20. This results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.29 mJy/beam.
The requested observations are sensitive to disks above the median disk mass of 0.005 Msolar in Taurus, rho Ophiuchus, and Orion (beyond the Trapezium cluster). We expect this to be sufficient to detect the AMC disks, as we have selected the brightest disks in Herschel maps (70 micron - 500 micron) and therefore expect these to be the most massive disks in the cloud. Disks with this mass were at the lower limit of ~20 disk masses that have been compiled over the years with the SMA (however they only had a S/N of 3).
We request the same mass sensitivity for Band 3 and Band 9 science goals.
The angular resolution requested is to resolve and therefore measure disk sizes. Disk radii in other regions are typically on the order of ~100 AU. Our requested angular resolution of 0.35" corresponds to ~160 AU at the AMC's distance. We request a maximum recoverable scale 10x this to safely account for the range in disk sizes without requiring configurations that are too compact and will result in shadowing for the AMC's declination (~35 degree). (We request the same resolution for science goals in other bands.)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B9 continuum: Protoplanetary Disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is a project to measure the spectral slopes of the brightest Class IIs in Auriga in the submm/mm regime.
This science goal is for the Band 9 (690 GHz) observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a sensitivity to detect 0.01 Msolar disk with a S/N of 20. This results in a continuum sensitivity of 4.1 mJy/beam.
The requested observations are sensitive to disks above the median disk mass of 0.005 Msolar in Taurus, rho Ophiuchus, and Orion (beyond the Trapezium cluster). We expect this to be sufficient to detect the AMC disks, as we have selected the brightest disks in Herschel maps (70 micron - 500 micron) and therefore expect these to be the most massive disks in the cloud. Disks with this mass were at the lower limit of ~20 disk masses that have been compiled over the years with the SMA (however they only had a S/N of 3).
We request the same mass sensitivity for Band 3 and Band 6 science goals.
The angular resolution requested is to resolve and therefore measure disk sizes. Disk radii in other regions are typically on the order of ~100 AU. Our requested angular resolution of 0.35" corresponds to ~160 AU at the AMC's distance. We request a maximum recoverable scale 10x this to safely account for the range in disk sizes without requiring configurations that are too compact and will result in shadowing for the AMC's declination (~35 degree). (We request the same resolution for science goals in other bands.)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 continuum and 12CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), HCN (4-3) and CS (7-6): Protoplanetary Disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This is a project to measure the spectral slopes of the brightest Class IIs in Auriga in the submm/mm regime.
This science goal is for the Band 7 (345 GHz) observations. These have a much lower mass sensitivity. The requested sensitivity is to ensure molecular line detections from the gas in the disks, to measure disk kinematics and is well matched to previous Band 7 obsrvations of disks in the OMC.
We observe the CO (3-2), HCO+ (4-3), HCN (4-3) and CS (7-6) and use the remaining channels for continuum observations.
The spectral resolution requested is to resolve molecular lines (expect widths a few km/s) while maximizing bandwidth for a measure of the continuum emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request a sensitivity to detect 0.2 mJy/beam to detect both continuum emission from the dust in the disks and molecular line emission from the gas in the disk. This sensitivity is matched to Cycle 0 observations of disks in the OMC (at a similar distance as the AMC). These Cycle 0 observations were able to detect gas in the brightest disks in the OMC (Mann et al. 2013, submitted) and therefore we match their specifications (bandwidth, resolution, and sensitivity) to observe the brightest disks in the AMC.
This results in a continuum sensitivity of 0.2 mJy/beam, which corresponds to a mass sensitivity of 0.0025 Msolar with a S/N of 20. This is well below the median disk mass of ~0.005 Msolar measured for other clouds (Taurus, rho Ophiuchus, and the OMC beyond the Trapezium cluster) and therefore we are highly confident we will detect our targeted disks. Additional integration time for the sensitivity to continuum emission is not needed.
As a result of the requested sensitivity to detect the molecular lines, the Band 7 mass sensitivities from the continuum emission are much deeper than the mass sensivitity requested for Band 3, Band 6 and Band 9 science goals.
The requested spectral resolution (0.8 km/s) is needed in order to measure the disk kinematics. Expected line widths are on the order of a few km/s. The disk kinematics will be used to measure the mass of the central stellar object and provide a physical context for the disk mass in relation to its host star.
This results in a high data rate (~22MB/s) but is necessary to acheive the required spectral resolution and (continuum) sensivitiy. By matching the spectral set up to Cycle 0 observations of disks in the OMC (PI Rita Mann), this will also make results between the two studies easily comparable.
The angular resolution requested is to resolve and therefore measure disk sizes. Disk radii in other regions are typically on the order of ~100 AU. Our requested angular resolution of 0.35" corresponds to ~160 AU at the AMC's distance. We request a maximum recoverable scale 10x this to safely account for the range in disk sizes without requiring configurations that are too compact and will result in shadowing for the AMC's declination (~35 degree). (We request the same resolution for science goals in other bands.)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Auriga-California molecular cloud (AMC) was recently identified as a member of the Gould Belt of nearby star-forming regions and is relatively unstudied. At a comparable distance and mass to Orion (OMC), it is forming 10x less stars, the most massive a B star. Using Spitzer, we have identified the protoplanetary disk hosts in the AMC, and we propose to target the 11 brightest detected with Herschel with ALMA Bands 3, 6, 7, and 9. We will use deep Band 7 continuum observations to measure the masses of the disks and molecular gas to measure their kinematics. We will use these, and other properties (e.g., temperature, size, density) to test the impact of environment on the potential for planet formation in the vicinity of an intermediate mass star, as a function of membership in groups within the cloud, and in comparison to the OMC. We will compile these with observations at Bands 3, 6, 9 and 7mm, 3cm, 5cm from the JVLA (all allocated or in hand) to measure the spectral slope of the sources to search for evidence of grain growth, the first stage of planet formation. We intend to follow up our best candidate for high resolution imaging in a future ALMA proposal cycle.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00794.S A first look of the disk properties in the Auriga GMC
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
